intro: Castilleja latifolia subsp. mendocinensis, commonly known as the Mendocino milkvetch, is a hemiparasitic plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its bright orange to red flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant has a slender, branching stem and produces small, elliptical leaves. It relies on other plants for some of its nutrients, making it a partial parasite. This subspecies is typically found in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and forest edges.
